social_posts.post_text:
900 RATINGS!!!!

I can’t believe it. 🥹 So soon to 1,000! That will be quite the milestone to celebrate! ☺️

I don’t have too many updates this week besides that I sent out my new novella this past Saturday to be beta read and I can’t wait to share more news on that soon! 😄🖤

I’m a little under the weather today so that’s all for now. 😅 How was everyone else’s week?

WIP: Owed to Me (tentative title)
CR: I just finished Such Sharp Teeth by Rachel Harrison (which was fantastic) and now I’m starting Year of the Witching by Alexis Henderson ☺️

I’m honor of Black history month, here are some of my favorite horror books written by Black voices. They’re all honestly MUST reads. So spooky and terrifying and horrific. 😱

Honorary mention goes to Darkly: Black History and America’s Gothic Soul by Leila Taylor. I truly believe EVERYONE needs to read this book. It’s a collection of essays on how horror is rooted deeply in black history. It was eye opening and written beautifully.

Planet Dead by @sylvesterbarzey (this is a zombie series! *wink wink* good for the fans who can’t get enough of The Last of Us!)
The Taking of Jake Livingston by Ryan Douglass
White Smoke by @writeinbk (The Weight of Blood by this author is also ridiculously amazing!)
Ring Shout by P. Djèlí Clark
When the Reckoning Comes by LaTanya McQueen

Have you read any of these? 🖤☺️

Vanilla’s 2 year book anniversary is coming up which is crazy because that means time is flying WAY too quickly. (It’s been 3 years since I wrote The Bell Chime 😱) I’d really like for time to calm down for a moment here so I can catch a breath. 🙃 Also is this how I’ll be measuring the sections of my life from now on? In published books? 😂

Vanilla was the first novel I ever wrote. She’s the first project I ever started on and I actually paused through the rewrite of her to write The Bell Chime amidst the pandemic. It took me about two years from start to finish to finally publish her so I guess she’s been alive for 4 years now. 😍

Of all my books, The Bell Chime definitely steals the spotlight but Vanilla holds a special place in my heart. It was the first time I actually saw myself being able to write and publish a book in full. 🖤

Anyway…. Vanilla is a couple reviews away from 100 on Goodreads so y’all should give her a read if you haven’t yet already! 👀 (Also be sure to drop those amazon reviews. 😝) I can guarantee you’ll enjoy her. And if that’s not enough convincing, here’s a creepy video to pitch her horrors to ya! 😆🖤

I know we all as avid readers are a little bit masochistic. I personally get very excited over books that surprise and shock me with absolute dread. Do you agree with my recommendations? Did they hurt you? 👀

Without spoilers, what else would you recommend? 🖤

I’m Thinking of Ending Things by Iain Reid
Tender is the Flesh by Agustina Bazterrica
The Silent Patient by Alex Michaelides

Good evening!!!

I hope everyone’s been having a lovely Sunday! Read a good book, do a face mask, and take care of yourself. 🖤💆🏻‍♀️

I’ve had a slow writing week. I’ve mainly been beta reading and editing which can be a nice  break but I’m still itching to get back into my writing sprints.

I’ll be receiving beta reader feedback soon for my latest novella and then I should be able to announce/reveal more which I’m truly excited about. ☺️ This month I also have two short stories to write. One of them has been started and it surrounds the life of a hobby baker who is trying to woo his office crush with baked treats until something possesses his… hand. 👀 It’s a fun and creepy concept and I’m excited to submit it to the anthology!

The Bell Chime is almost at 1,000 reviews!! It’s about 10 reviews off. I think that by the time we check in with each other next week, it will have hit that number. 🤩 My eyes are going to literally pop out of my head when I see the milestone for real. 😬

How has everyone else’s week been? What are we working on? What are we reading? ☺️

CR: Beta reading
WIP: Untitled
Featured book: For You by Mona Kabbani

This past week, The Bell Chime hit 1,000 ratings on Goodreads!!! 🎉 🎊

I can still barely believe it. And the number keeps rising. 🥹 I want to thank everyone who has loved and supported this novella. It’s because of you that this story has spread so far and wide and been able to reach so many souls. 🖤 I will be over here crying from gratefulness in the corner.

In other news…
This week I’m working on some edits/revisions for my new novella. I will have that sent out by the end of this week which is exciting. I’m also gearing up for AuthorCon II which is fast approaching!!! If you will be attending, drop a comment and let me know!! If you’re not, you should reconsider and come because it’s going to be an amazing time!

I’d also like to leave a reminder that I have signed copies of all of my books for sale. Just shoot me a DM or check out the link in my bio to order. ☺️

Happy Monday, y’all! Let’s kick this week’s boot-ay! 💪🏼

CR: Haunting Adeline by H.D. Carlton
WIP: The Color of Blood (title change from Owed to Me)

It has come to my attention that not everyone knows they can purchase signed copies of my books directly through me! So I wanted to start off this weekly post with a friendly reminder that if you can’t find or order my books at your local indie bookstore and/or you don’t want to purchase through Amazon, you can purchase directly through me. Just shoot me a DM. ☺️

In other news, VANILLA has been chosen as @betweenthepagesbookstore ‘s Horror Book of the Month!! It’s an honor for her to be chosen as she holds a special place in my dark heart and I hope everyone who reads her loves her just as much! 🖤 Although THE BELL CHIME is my first published work, VANILLA is the first book I started my writing journey on, taking about 2 years to complete. So it always makes me happy when she’s receiving the attention I feel she deserves!

It’s Women’s History Month, which means we get to give some extra celebration to all the amazing Women in Horror! I have some reel ideas to come where I’ll post about my favorite horror books written by women! (And there are so, so many.)

My latest novella was just turned into the publisher this morning, so I’ll have some more news on that I think by the end of the month! Speaking of the end of the month… AuthorCon II is so close I can almost TASTE it! I’ll be there signing and selling all 3 of my books and I hope to see you there too!!! ☺️ Drop a comment if you’re attending!! 🖤

CR: Haunting Adeline by @hdcarltonauthor
WIP: Sweet Teeth (tentative short story title)

Authorcon was so amazing. Despite being a writer, I have no words to describe the feelings I get from this event and from meeting all my fellow writers, readers, and hanging out with my friends. I’m thankful my friends are better at taking pictures than I am so I can cherish those memories! But that just goes to show how I wanted to absorb every moment and how positively overwhelmed I was.

Thanks to every single one of you for such an amazing convention. Until next time. 🖤

This did extraordinarily well on the ⏰ app so I’m posting it here to see what happens. 👀 Also wanted to say Hi! 👋🏼 I’M ALIVE! I know I’ve been hyper inactive here and that’s because a/ I’ve been busy between AuthorCon and writing and shipping books, tis been CHAOS, and b/ Insta algorithm likes to play with me and I’m tired of these games. 🙅🏻‍♀️

ANYWAY I JUST WANTED TO ANNOUNCE A SMOL THING SO PLEASE READ ON:
I’ve updated my website! You can now purchase signed editions of my books at any time via link in bio or morality in horror dot com!! I hope you’ll check out the updated site, buy some books, and sign up for my newsletter. ☺️ I’m thinking i’m going to start releasing small clips of what I’ve been writing to my newsletter subscribers for anyone interested. 👀🖤

That is all, thank you so much for sticking around to read this chaotic lil update. ✨ You rock my socks, babe. 🖤

The Bell Chime has hit 1500 ratings! ✨🖤🥳

It’s actually a bit more than that now and still rising. I’m just so ecstatic and in disbelief. Of all my books I never expect TBC to be such a hit but I’m glad it is, even if everyone gets to read about my trauma. 🥲

As many of you may or may not know, I have been in the process of moving. I’m essentially all moved in now, just a few more things to grab from my old place and then some decorations to really make this apartment feel like home! Although it’s already starting to come together tremendously. ☺️ I might share a few pictures of our decorations if anyone is interested.

Other than that, I’m grinding away on this new novel. Almost at the 50K milestone. It’s taken quite a dark turn for what I originally intended to be more smut than horror, but what can I say? I am a ghoul at my core. 🖤

I’ve felt pretty disconnected so what’s everyone else up to? I’d love to hear what you’re all working on, reading, planning, what kind of animal you’re currently petting! I’m currently reading Brother by @aniaahlborn and I’m already blown away! I can’t wait to finish it!!!

(PS, Jack and I have been watching A LOT of true crime docs lately so if any of you have any good recommendations, please share! 📸)

GRWM to tell you about my books!! 🥰 📚

All books are available on Amazon or I SELL SIGNED COPIES ON MY WEBSITE. You can check that out 👀, maybe sign up for my not-yet-existent newsletter while you’re there. 👀 Go nuts. 👀 Go wild! 😜

I hope everyone is having a lovely monday!!! 🖤✨

I haven’t done a review like this in a while which is unfortunate because I actually really enjoyed doing reviews for Instagram in this format. I think it was because I felt so much pressure to look impeccable in all my pictures and write these really nice elaborate reviews and they DID bring me joy but also a lot of stress. So I’m trying something different because I miss talking about books and sharing what I’m reading and discussing with you all. Also, I feel this book deserves it!

Just Like Home by Sarah Gailey from @torbooks WOW! What a ride. 🏚️💕

So for the first 90% of this book, I was like ‘what the heck is going on here???’ The writing style is GORGEOUS although a touch too thick at parts. Sarah Gailey definitely knows how to set the mood for every detail with their comparisons to the point where I needed to reread all the beautiful similes to appreciate their full impact!!!! (This was also an act of studying on my part because they write exactly how I aspire to write.)

I had almost given up on this book having any real plot which is FINE because I enjoy *vibes only* books. But the last 10% hooked me by the mouth and reeled me in like a FISH 🎣 I wish this last section was LONGER! I wish we got to see MORE of the new development, but alas, I am left wanting. I can’t really speak more on it because it’s a spoiler although I wish I could because it is amazing. ❌

Fantastic haunted house story with a really sweet but disturbing twist. GET IT. 🏚️💕🏚️

Holy wow, what a ride! Let me begin by saying I am not familiar with Karin Slaughter’s work. I was under the impression she wrote airport thrillers—maybe Pretty Girls is a deviation from the norm or maybe my initial impression was wrong but this book reads to me like a horror novel! It is graphic and I was not aware of the level of explicitly I was walking myself into. As a horror lover, I was amazed. As a person living in a society that bleeds these atrocities, I was terrified.

It’s funny because the first half of this book DOES read like an airport thriller. I kinda thought, okay well wealthy housewife whose now dead husband has a terrible secret… but it ESCALATED. For a 600 page book, I do think the first half coulda been cut down, but the writing style was easy and fluid so it made reading a joy.

If you’re looking for a true crime nightmare… welp, look no further.

(Thank you to @baker_reads for putting me onto this book!)

Happy Father’s Day! Iykyk 🩸 🍭 💉

As always, signed copies of all my books are available on my website via link in my bio! 📚 Celebrate the day and pick up a book! 🥰

What are you doing for father’s day? Unfortunately, I will be on a flight back to New York soon but spending the morning with my dad, having apple pie! 🥧🖤

Oh, hey! 👋🏼 How’s it going? What’s up? Watcha doing?

I have had QUITE the month (if I’m being honest, quite the YEAR). My eyelid is literally twitching as I write this. 🐝 

I’m getting back into my book reviews which I’m actually really happy about. I lost the taste for doing reviews for a while when it all became too stressful but now the ebb is flowing and I look forward to sharing more about what I’m currently reading! 🥰

Last I left off with you all, I was working on an erotica horror novel HOWEVER I ~finally~ received a rejection for a novel I submitted two years ago and a lovely publisher that I don’t want to name yet until things are solidified has agreed to take a look at it. 😄 So I’m currently freshening up that manuscript to be delivered by the end of June. We will see what happens then. 👀📚

I’m also working on a short story for an arab horror anthology which is spectacular. I don’t see much arab horror and of course mine veers more on the psychological but from the synopses I’ve heard so far from my fellow short story submitters, this anthology will be EPIC! More news on that to come.

On a more personal note, I got a FitBit last week and have been LOVING the badges I receive for different milestones. Paired with my walking treadmill, I’m living the fit life large. If anyone wants to be friends on FitBit, hit me up. 👀

Finally, I know you already know this but I want to remind you because I like you so much: signed copies of any of my books are available on my website in the link in my bio!! Please purchase so I can buy new press on nails. 💅🏻🖤

THANK YOU!!!!☠️💞

Happy Saturday! I hope everyone is having a wonderful start to their weekend! ✨🥰
🐰
Cursed Bunny by Bora Chung:

What a lovely little collection of short stories! I’ve been wanting to read this ever since I saw it plastered all over Instagram and I fell in love with the title. 🐇 These felt more like moral fables you’d read in some centuries old book rather than horror stories to tell over the fire. But nonetheless, they will leave you distraught. 👀

My top three of the bunch:
Snare — this story both mystified and enraged me. I’d like to believe that if given the opportunity, no one would take advantage of an innocent, but alas, humanity always has a funny way of surprising me. The imagery is brilliant and it read to me like a Junji Ito story.

Goodbye, My Love — this was a story straight out of a Black Mirror episode. The ending was so bizarre and strange, I was left entirely uncomfortable which of course I love. 😆

Scars — I wish this story was a touch longer and explained a bit more but it was such a heartbreaking ending with absolutely no happiness in sight. Just bleak hope and trauma.

Overall, a collection I would not pass up! I binged it in two days so it’s a nice light read for those not looking to get into stories that are too complex but offer rich food for thought. 🦊 🤖 🦅

It is a rainy day here in NYC! 🌧️ ☔️

Which is unfortunate because I wanted to go outside for a little bit to get some sun but I have been cloud-blocked. My new apartment windows face another building mere FEET away so all I see is wet brick. 😆😭

I’ve been chugging along revising that rejected manuscript I have. It’s crazy how my writing has evolved over two years. Reading this MS and thinking about how I write now, it’s almost like two different writers. 😳 I will have it ready and handed over to the publishing press by the end of July. 👏🏼 He’s nearing 50,000 + words now so I’m thinking he’ll keep Vanilla company in the chonkster category. 🤞🏼

I also have like 3 other books ideas I wish I could be working on at the same time. 🥲 But one step—or should I say one PAGE at a time. Hahahahaha.

In other news, Jack and I binge watched all the Evil Dead movies this past weekend. Army of Darkness KILLED me—I couldn’t stop laughing. Jack says the first Evil Dead scared him the most and I would have to agree although Evil Dead Rises was SPECTACULAR! What are your thoughts? 👀

I am also just about done with The Exorcist. 10% to go!! It’s friggin amazing so far and I know my review will just be glowing praise. 👹😈

Okay, thanks for reading! Don’t forget you can buy signed copies of my books on my website!!! 😘🖤✨ KTHNX

Happy Friday!!! 😈🥳🖤

I hope everyone has been given a long weekend to relax, pick up a book, and binge until you realize it’s 3am!

I don’t have a review for The Exorcist prepared for you and that is because I don’t think I can give you a review. To me, this is a PERFECT novel. The characters and their development are heart-wrenching, the plot is set to a sublime pace, and the writing is positively exquisite. All I can do is gush.

So if you wish to gush alongside me in the comments, I’m right there with you. I also rewatched the movie this week for the second time in probably over 7 years. I’m happy I forgot basically the entire movie before reading and rewatching because it gave me an ENTIRELY different perspective on the story from when I watched it as a young, foolish ghoul who just thought it was some old horror movie. 🤭

The Exorcist is one for the “to be read again and again and again” pile. 📚

Right now, I am reading A Head Full of Ghosts by @paulgtremblay (a lot of possession novels lately!!) and I’m absolutely loving it. It’s gonna be so lovely to read by the lake this weekend. ☺️

I hope you all have a fabulous long weekend! 🧨 🎆 Ta-ta!

An aching part of me wants to move out of the city and live in a cabin on the lake. 🌳🌊

Instead I live this dream vicariously by visiting my friend’s cabin on the lake. 😆

I finished A Head Full of Ghosts this weekend by Paul Tremblay and will post a review of it soon! What a PERFECT book to read by the water. I couldn’t be happier.

I don’t have much else to report! Just another reminder that signed copies of ALL my psychologically warped horror books are available to purchase on my website in the link in my bio! (Please put my website to WORK 🥵)

I hope everyone is having a marvelous hump day. 🐫💋🖤

I cannot stop thinking about this book. What I thought would be a classic demonic possession story became something so much more.

I’ve been on an exorcism kick, reading demonic possession after demonic possession, never growing tired. But of all the stories, this book threw me in for a loop. I don’t even want to say too much about it because I went in entirely blind and I think everyone should too. I’m sure most have already read this book but this was my first time and I’m in awe.

I still don’t know what I believe happened. I still don’t know the truth of this story. I only know that it hurt.

If you read the Exorcist and have been searching for the same rush William Peter Blatty gave you, then I highly recommend this book. I think in terms of plot development, references, writing style, it’s pretty darn close to the beloved classic but with a sour twist that will leave you reeling! 👹👻

(Also, kind of spoilery ❌⚠️ so don’t read on if you don’t want any hints….

but this book gave me mega We Have Always Lived in the Castle vibes, which is one of the best unreliable narrator narratives I’ve read. So A+ to that!)

Today is my beloved @jemihall ‘s birthday!!! 🥳 🎂 🎉 Say Happy Birthday to the old man >:]!!!

I was looking through photos and realize I have very few photographs from this past year of us together! It must be due to our new life; we moved in together, you’re studying for the bar to become the amazing lawyer I know you will be, and I’m trying to balance 2 jobs at once. But I found this photo. It must be two years old now because you still have your bleached hair. I love this photo. It embodies us. This year, we must do better to take new photos! 📸☺️

So yeah, everyone wish Jack the happiest of birthday’s please! I can’t wait to celebrate tonight! 🥳🖤

Demonic possession/exorcism books you MUST read! 👹👻

As many of you may, or may not know, I have been on a huge demonic possession book binge. Many of these I’ve read back to back. It’s so interesting to see how the stories differ despite using the same trope. I friggin LOVE it!

If you have any demonic possession book recommendations, please drop them in the comments below! 👇🏼 I must read more. 👁️👄👁️

I have not been able to stop thinking about Come Closer by Sara Gran since I read it a week (maybe two weeks?) ago.

This is one of those books that hit me in the soft, spongey, dark section of my central nervous system long forgotten since coming into adulthood. It’s the part that once reveled in all the childish frivolity and naïveté I held so easily in my heart but now find difficult to grant myself.

It’s the part that trusted so readily and could be betrayed with ease.

In this book, our main character is betrayed by what she believes to be her childhood imaginary friend. She trusts this friend because it’s just that—a friend. A piece of her childhood held so dear. But it wasn’t what she thought, it had no good intentions, and in the end it destroys her and her life.

I can’t exactly press my tongue on why this concept brings me such sadness. Maybe just the idea that nostalgic memories could come back and slip under our skin to bite us? Maybe the idea that everything we saw as children wasn’t so bright and cheery and there to help guide us?

All of this monologue to say of all the books with demons and ghouls in em’, this one hit me closest to home and if you’re looking for something that will ache, I cannot recommend this enough. It deserves a reread from me in the near future. 🖤 Bravo, Sara Gran. I will be reading more of your work soon.

I will recommend feral women until the day I die. Please read all of these book, thank you. 🖤🔪

Boy Parts by @fancyeliza (my personal favorite)
Maeve Fly by CJ Leede
A Certain Hunger by Chelsea G. Summers

I am both in awe and so frustrated with this one.

I found myself a touch underwhelmed. Don’t get me wrong, the writing, setting, emotions were all exquisite. As someone who essentially lives between New York and LA, I love seeing these cities portrayed through a misanthrope’s eyes. This IS a fabulous book. However, when I read about unhinged women, I want it to be unapologetic. I want their downfall to be a middle finger to the sky as they’re dragged into hell. This book did not have that element and in the end, I feel we were meant to pity a character who I could not truly categorize as sane or disturbed if not for the graphic gore but somewhere in the weird murky middle. I loved the not so subtle nod to American Psycho (one of my favorite books) but it seemed out of place within the entirety of the book. Maybe because there was a romance that humanized the two when that didn’t seem to be the point?

I recommend this book. It’s crazy and fun and exciting to read about a deranged disney princess roaming the streets of LA. I just wish it gave me a touch more emotional depravity or leaned a bit more into the romance if that’s the avenue it wished to travel.

What are everyone else’s thoughts??? 👸🏼👁️

Hello! 👋🏼 Here’s a writing update!

I haven’t posted a writing update in a while because I’ve been so busy! 🤪 (I have been posting a lot on Threads so be sure to follow me there if you haven’t already! 🧵 🪡)

I’m currently working on like…. three Manuscripts. Maybe not at the same exact time but in a round about way. One MS I am actively working on every day because I’ve had to extend my deadline with the publisher a couple times now. The notorious serial killer, Andrew Compton, has made his escape. He’s faked death and managed to break free from the confines of his prison cell, depositing him into the streets of London where he wreaks havoc. Needing to move on, lest he gets caught again, Compton travels to the city of New Orleans where he assumes a new life and a fresh start. He does not expect to meet Jay Bryne, a like-minded killer with a penchant for morbid art. He especially never expected to fall in love. Will their spree of murders flourish or will they find themselves free-falling into tragedy, taking their victims along with them?

Blood, guts, and true love. Despite the alluring narrative, in my opinion this book doesn’t start until 60% in. That being said, I thoroughly enjoyed the last 40%. But the first 60% really didn’t add anything for me in terms of character development or plot.

Sick and twisted Dahmer-like serial killers finding their own sordid version of love is an exquisite (get it?) concept and the writing is like none I’ve read before—enchanting and blithely sardonic. Yet something failed so tragically for me here and I think it was purely the pacing. I’d still highly recommend as I’m VERY glad I finally got around to reading this, I just wish some literary wrench was taken to the binding and the storyline tightened just a tweak or two.

Please check trigger warnings if need be. This book is a doozy.

Louise’s parents have just died in a tragic car accident. It’s been some time since she last saw them, and she doesn’t want to travel back home to deal with the funeral. That would mean leaving her daughter behind and returning to the memories of her strange childhood. But alas, family calls and she books a flight to Charleston where she is reunited with her estranged brother, Mark, and boy, does he hate her. With ownership of the family home transferred by will to Mark, the siblings decide to sell. Only selling will be quite difficult. Because you see, it turns out their childhood home is VERY haunted. 🏡
 Grady Hendrix is the master of absurdism mixed with some of the best character development I have ever read. Between his books about haunted furniture stores, hot-dog-loving exorcists, and book-club vampire slayers, this novel featuring demonic puppets is so on brand. Standing at a little over 400 pages, it does get repetitive at points, but it is repetitive with action which, if you’re ever gonna be redundant, at least let it be exciting. 🧸
 Mark was such an endearing character. At first I HATED him but I’m so surprised over how much he grew on me. And that’s the power of Hendrix—his ability to conjure multi-faceted characters you end up wanting the best for. I love the mending of family trauma and watching an estranged relationship restore to its rightful amicability. The final chapter really tugged at my heartstrings and solidified the full circle of loss, grief, and unconditional familial love. 🚚

An excellent haunted house story limned with humor and heartache—I highly recommend. ☺️🏡

“I don’t fear death… but they do.”

Muriel McAuley has lived in Witchaven all her life. It’s where she met Billy, fell in love, had her children, and waited in horror the day Billy went out to sea and never returned. It’s where she plans to die. Now that horrible billionaire, Patrick Grant, wants to tear her home down to make way for a golf course. And he is relentless, sending lackey after intimidating lackey to push her out. But Muriel is stubborn. During one of her scenic walks, she happens upon a slime in the grass that speaks to her through thoughts. Thinking it some new species of sea animal, she brings it home, cares for it, only to find it is something beyond her wildest nightmares of the ocean.

Would you fall in love with a murderous sea creature that only has your best intentions at heart? Honestly… I might. This story for all its gore and injustice was surprisingly… adorable. 😆 I absolutely love Muriel as a character. She is so righteous with a hard edge and very relatable. A well-rounded character who I wanted nothing but the best for. And I think Avalon gave that to her in the most romantically disturbing way. 🥹🖤 🌊

I love battle-for-nature stories with revenge. The Haar was excellently paced, an easy read to breeze through, and stirred in me rainbow of emotion. I was angry then happy then disgusted then sad then infuriated then exuberant. Haha, really everything under the sun. ☀️

I’ve already loaded another David Sodergren book into my kindle—Maggie’s Grave—and can’t wait to get into it. I loved this book so I’m certain I’ll love his other works too. If you want a revenge horror story set in Scotland with a romantically disturbing plot, PICK THIS UP! 🐙

What does it take to kill a child? Following the death of their mother, young Jude and Kyle are subjected to the unsavory pastimes of their deviant uncles. I don’t wanna go much deeper into the book’s content just because it’s so harrowing and traumatizing. I think you get the gist.

Only the Stains Remain by Ross Jeffery is primarily a revenge story that hits like a locomotive. It begins with an adult Jude navigating the retribution he so desires after all these years of lost innocence. I like that the book parallels the narrative of the trauma that occurs in the former years with the revenge in the latter because if this ran in chronological order, it would be difficult to digest. That said, I  also appreciate how Jeffery balances the abuse by not divulging too much in the imagery but not diminishing the impact these actions have on the psyche of a developing child. RE: the reference to the initial question: What does it take to kill a child? Because it’s not just a physical death. It can be a psychological one.

Only the Stains Remain is an excellent title for a story like this because that is what trauma to this degree can feel like to the victim. A stain that can never be washed away no matter how much you scrub or whatever retribution you succeed at. And it’s very apparent the irreparable damage done onto Jude. You get the sense that he knows—whatever he accomplishes in these 120 pages will never fix him.

I’m terribly squeamish about abuse, especially with children, but Jeffery narrated this story in a respectful way that made me more sad and empathetic than appalled and mortified. I know it can be a difficult topic but if you’re looking for a killer revenge story that’ll leave you hollowed out, this novella is a heartbreaking read you can find on KU!

Please check trigger warnings if need be.

'I really think hell is real,' said Dolly. 'But I think we make it. I think people create tiny hells. Little pocket dimensions, little hell dimensions.’

Have you heard about her? Read about her? Consumed fragmented factoids about what they did to her? Do you know what they did to her? Do you really know?
Joan Wilson was burned alive by three of her classmates. They thought they got away with it, that if Joan was found in a burned down chalet, the police would assume it was an accident. And maybe they would’ve, except Joan Wilson got up and walked without her skin, alerting the entire town of Crow-On-Sea to criminal wrong doing. The question is, what really happened? What led to this vile murder?

Wow. Seriously, wow. I am blown away. I was curious if Eliza Clark could top her previous release, Boy Parts (which wound up being an all-time favorite), and I think she absolutely did. I think this is a new addition to my list of books I will never stop recommending.

If you’re a true crime fanatic like me, you will FROTH over this book, and even if you’re not—even if you’re looking for something more haunting and disturbing—you will lose all traction with reality and ascend into the most bizarre, delusional narrative I have ever been graced with laying eyes on. So yeah, you could say I freaking loved this book.

Penance is a meta novel about a disgraced journalist covering all the layers of insanity that led to a murder’s climax. The book is limned with dark goodies from the dregs of the internet, including the toxic, polarizing culture of the hyper niche, insular, troubled communities found on Tumblr. I used Tumblr, I frequented 4Chan and reddit, I read creepypasta as a child and it was so throttling to read about what I now realize was concerning access to disturbing websites molding the minds of sick teenagers. That’s what makes this book so haunting—how it hit so close to home.

So yeah, true crime fanatics and all horror lovers curious about the horrifying darkness that lies beneath the world wide web, gallop to your nearest library, bookstore, computer, and purchase a copy of Penance. You won’t regret it.

l write things that make me happy and if they make others happy too, then that’s all the better. 🥹🖤

“You can’t love someone if you’re afraid of them, Mariana.”

When Mariana receives a call from her beloved niece, Zoe, that Tara has been brutally murdered on the Cambridge campus, Mariana books a train ticket right away. She returns to her old college and is transported back in time to when she met her deceased husband, Sebastian, on these very grounds. But Sebastian is gone now—only Zoe remains and Mariana is determined to take good care of her. When Zoe points Mariana in the direction of the alluring and eccentric professor, Edward Fosca, she is certain she has found the killer.

In Michaelides fashion, this was a mind twister. After reading the Silent Patient, I KNEW this plot would not be as simple as it seems and although I feverishly searched for the truth, I was still wrong in the end. I was aware there would be a twist, I spent the book fabricating absolutely wild possible endings, and yet, I was still shocked by the final reveal. I love that. Michaelides makes a note in his acknowledgements that this book is like a love letter to Agatha Christie and other iconic mystery writers and I think he hit the mark in this homage.

I love the murder mystery on a famous college campus theme—it gives dark academia vibes. I love the idea of a hidden cult of students who may or may not be colluding. I love that this book was light on the descriptions and a breeze to read through. A great palate cleanser between heavier books. I think there are a few threads of plot that weren’t properly knotted in my opinion. I think there were some themes and subplots I would have loved more focus on. But overall, I had a lot of fun!! If you were a fan of the Silent Patient or are just looking for a murder mystery to breeze through with a shocking twist, check this out! 📖

“I’m going to stay here and let the house make me disappear.”

Eric and his two daughters, Dess and Stacy, are on the run from something they cannot explain. Something terrible that has thrown their entire lives off balance. Even as they distance themselves from their past, they’re not sure where their future lies. They live day by day, hoping to find a haven to call home even if it’s just for a little while. What becomes their harbor is a spite house in the small town of Degener, Texas, known to many and feared by all.

A unique twist on the Gothic haunted house story finds its roots in a small town in Texas. An aspect of this plot reminds me of Vincent Price’s House On Haunted Hill where a wealthy mogul invites a group of unsuspecting party-goers to survive a night. Vincent Price in this book is our wealthy, blithe millionaire (perhaps billionaire?), Eunice, the despot of Degener. Her motives are ambiguous as she invites Eric and his two children to stay in the spite house for a ridiculous sum of money. And us as the readers want to scream at her to tell the truth!

I’m stuck in the middle regarding my thoughts. On the one hand, the writing is succinct and clear; I trusted the narrative to guide me through. On the other hand, I feel a tad betrayed. The building blocks of this plot were rationale I do not believe made much sense. There were character choices I squinted at and thought to myself, Really? Why? There were important plot threads we seemed resolved to let fray in the wind, unanswered. I’m not entirely sure what happened. And for a haunted house story, we spent less time in the house than in auxiliary characters’ heads which I didn’t too much care for.

However! There was a scene in this book that IGNITED my gooseflesh and I am always highly appreciative when a story can do that. *tips hat* Yes, good on you, sir. Thank you. Never one to deter readers, if you’re aching for that haunted house fix and want to try something new, something with high-stakes and greed, enter the walls of the spite house and see if you can survive the night… 🏚️

(also, I’m wearing a cute Halloween sweater and a lil bit frustrated that it’s hard to see!)

As many of you know, I am a HUGE fan of Tender is the Flesh. 🍖  So when Agustina Bazterrica announced her newest work—a collection of short stories—I foamed at the mouth like a rabid dog. 😬🐶

It took me about three days to finish Nineteen Claws and a Black Bird, a collection of 19 literary short horror stories ranging from grotesque to subtle to just plain bizarre. 🐦‍⬛ I must preface this by saying I’ve never been the BIGGEST fan of short story collections. I like when stories get me emotionally invested and then ruin me from the inside out. Short stories simply do not have the length to thoroughly mess me up. However, I was in a reading slump this past week and found myself unable to commit to ANYTHING, so this book was genuinely perfect for what I needed. 📚

Each story is short, quick, and portrait-like. Like reading the synopses of classic and violent paintings. 🖼️ Some were so metaphorical or bogged down with symbolism, I wasn’t always entirely sure what was going on. Which is probably my own fault since reading comprehension comes as a difficulty to me despite my love of reading. 😂 Very nebulous and ambiguous without much emotional impact. If I wasn’t in that slump, I prob wouldn’t have enjoyed this as much!! But the beauty of books is having a variety to adjust to our varying moods so I’m glad my library hold on this was available at just the right time. 🥰

If you haven’t read any of Bazterrica’s works, this could be a fabulous introduction to her writing style. However, nothing tops Tender is the Flesh for me… yet. 🥩

(ps, Obligatory nail 📸 incoming: I haven’t shown off my new nails yet 💅🏻 so swipe for a glimpse. These might be my favorite yet 😳 …. although I say that about all of them. 😂🖤)

I owe you a review because I said I would post it last week and then I got side-swiped by the locomotive that is life and only just got my affairs back in order today. 😮‍💨

So, here we go:

This. Was. Phenomenal.

And that’s it. That’s the review. Go watch it.

Just kidding—but seriously, this movie blew me away. It set me back to my default factory settings. It wiped out my CPU and downloaded a trojan virus where I just spin in circles all day wondering non-stop about this movie.

Talk To Me is about a the hand of a medium encased in porcelain that allows people to contact the dead. But as alcohol campaigns say, consume responsibly. The effects might be wonderfully euphoric but hold hands with it for too long and you might find yourself irreparably f*cked.

As many of you know, I am a psychological horror girlie 💅🏻 so I’m a big fan of anything character driven and unreliable. The paranoia and distrust I had for basically every character throttled me to my very core. I will say, for the length and sake of pacing for this movie, it achieved all I could have wanted perfectly. I MAYBE could have the argument that if a bunch of teens found out spirits were real, they’d probably have more of an existential crisis moment rather than turning it into a “drug addiction”… at least at first. But whatever, it’s a horror movie and who needs pristine logic when the concept is so ridiculously interesting???

The ending was insane albeit ambiguous. Normally I like my finales to be tied up in the most perfect, glittery black bow but because of the nature of the whole movie, the ending suited it well. It’s one of those movies I want to watch again, not because I necessarily think I’ll catch what I missed last now that I know the ending, but because I need a second round to properly process the absolute fist of paranoia and psychosis that punched me right in the frontal lobe.

So yeah, you could say I’m quite fond of this movie. Hopefully this review pushes you to watch it and if not… well fine but also boo. I think you’d really like it. (PS. I saw a letterbox review say this was a more effective anti-drug campaign than all of D.A.R.E. and that made me giggle 🤭)
🤚🏼🫲🏻

The Court of Shadows by @victordixen is a French to English translation of a historical horror fantasy set in Versailles! 🇫🇷 A baroque and horrifying alternate history, it tackles the alluring and demonic appeal of vampires. Set in 1715, a young woman, Jean Froidelac, seeks revenge on a vampire king for the murder of her family. What with Astarion from Baldur’s Gate 3, vampiric revenge is all the rage right now. 🦇 🖤🩸 Thank you so much to the publisher, @otrpr , for this wonderful copy! (slideshow contains more pictures of my nails because you know I’m all about that documentation and their beauty deserves to be preserved. 😝 i needed jack to help me with the lighting of these and in one picture you can see him making fun of me. 🤪 💅🏻)

“It was a fury and viciousness that didn’t exist in nature. That is what we have created, Hannah thought.”

Joe Gerhard has something of a sordid job. In fact, it’s downright morally reprehensible. But he tells himself it’s for the greater good. They’re saving people. They’re saving lives. With this personally defined compass, he operates his day to day just fine. In fact, he’s the best supervisor the company has seen. Until one day, his work follows him home. Joe has always seen himself as a supervisor first and a father second, but will this incursion change the tides?

An absolutely gruesome tale showcasing the poor prioritization between corporate and familial responsibility. Joe is a man like many others who puts his job first and believes that working longer and harder makes him a better father even though he’s missed out on most of his daughter’s childhood. But he’s providing. He’s funding the success of her future. And with quite the job… 🧬

I don’t wanna give too much away because I went into this blind. I knew there was human experimentation but I didn’t know to what extent or for why. Discovering that as I read was a horrifying realization and one that kept the pages turning. 📖🩸👀

That said, I believe this unique, heart-racing concept of gore and horror was what kept me glued to the pages. I felt the characters were 2D and had difficulty envisioning them as real people in my head. All their wants and desires pretty much boiled down to survival. Which yes, of course, but very little depth beyond that. Because I wasn’t invested in the characters themselves, it made reading all the bloody horrors more… pleasant in a way? Like I was just fascinated and repulsed by the overall concept and imagery rather than emotionally mortified by the fate of our cast. Which was a pretty cool reading experience. 👀 Definitely a novel to check out if you’re looking for sci-fi horror! 🧬🦠💉💊🩺🧫🧪🌡️

“A real hunter should only rely on oneself.”

One humble evening like any other, before a boiling pot of pheasant stew, Jeanne Froidelac witnesses the merciless butchering of her entire family. When the Shadow King’s dragoons turn on her, she narrowly escapes with her life, instead taking on the identity of her village’s baronette and tricking the vampire sent to hunt her into escorting her to the Court of Shadows in Versailles for a rewarding tutelage. But the only thing on Jeanne’s mind is revenge, even if she cannot decide on the deserving target.

I love vampires. I absolutely LOVE them even when they’re evil. But this book had me hating them and for good reason. The Court of Shadows by Victor Dixen dictates a world where the French monarchy is taken over by vampirism and classes are defined by mortality, leaving commoners in villages to give a monthly tithe to their royal rulers in blood. An amount of blood they can barely withstand. All mortals except for the few in nobility are seen as cattle and, my goodness how horribly they’re treated.

Although I was on and off with my love for Jeanne, her morals continuously churning through variants of grey, it was exciting to read about the court and its rich characters through her eyes. I particularly adored Naoko and want to read more of her story—she has some secrets I find myself so very nosey about. 👀 And as it turns out, I’m in luck! This book ends on a cliffhanger with more to come! I’m not exactly sure how many installments come hereafter but I’m certain the world will only expand into something ornately tremendous. After all, there are still so many interesting characters to learn about. 💋

If you’re looking for a baroque, dark fantasy retelling of 18th century Versailles with not a single idle moment, this one’s for you! 🧛🏻‍♀️🩸

It’s chronic. @spencer.hamilton.books , I fight my inner demons for you. 🖤😂

I can’t stop thinking about this documentary. I can’t stop thinking about Amy and what became of her and how this all “ended.” So I need to talk about it.

If you don’t know, Love Has Won was a cult started by Amy Carlson, AKA Mother God, who believed herself to be god on earth. The physical embodiment of the divine along with her counterpart, Father God; a roll that was always filled but not necessarily by the same man over the course of her life. Many found Amy online, followed her, believed her, and moved to California to live in a large cabin with other followers. I think they say there were 20 plus people living there at one time, all doing drugs constantly, all praising Mother God and her teachings.

The documentary goes into much more detail about the individual members, how they moved around quite a bit, and attempts to dissect what exactly they were preaching, which I still am not certain of. But what I can’t stop thinking about is Amy’s deterioration. How all the cult members WATCHED her waste away and called it “ascension.” I cannot get this out of my head. I know the HBO documentary does not dive into all the minutia—I am sure many events were skimmed over or ignored entirely—so these are my thoughts having only watched this sole documentary.

Amy Carlson was someone who needed help. She was sick. She had delusions that indicated something potentially in need of medical treatment and her “panic attacks” seemed more like psychotic breaks to me which were further exacerbated by the extreme drug abuse. THAT is why I can’t stop thinking about this doc. About how this woman needed attention of the medical/therapeutic variety not the cult variety, and everyone around her encouraged her instead because they thought Robin Williams was going to pick her up in the galactic spaceship (???), leading to the horrifying conclusion of her life.

I am going to be haunted by this for a while. I simply cannot digest the morality of all this coming from the followers and make it make sense. 😢 If you decide to watch Love Has Won, be warned. It takes its mental toll.

One day, I had the bright idea to “hack” my writing productivity. I wanted to write an entire novella on my phone alone. It made sense to me because I spend so much time on my phone as I commute on the subway or wait for appointments, so why not use those snippets of time to write a book? ✍🏼 📖

I had google docs downloaded, I got to chapter two, and then rage quit because the formatting on the tiny screen was impossible to read and I just needed to use my computer. 😆 💻

I think it’s definitely possible to at least write a short story but I just couldn’t achieve long form on my tiny phone screen. I wonder if anyone has succeeded at this though. 🤔

Have you ever attempted to hack your writing productivity?

Looking for the cozy comfort of a few uplifting Christmas short stories? Well don’t look here! 🎄

This Christmas, Santa is letting it all hang out, and trust me, it ain’t pretty. 😆 This short story collection contains the sordid imaginations of three amazing extreme horror authors: @kristopher_triana @aronbeauregardhorror @dj_volpe_horror ! And it was such a treat to read the disgusting Holiday horror corruptions they conjured into this universe. White Christmas? More like a pulpy red one!🎅🏼😆

I don’t know of many extreme horror stories written around the holidays (I’m sure they exist but I’m just unaware of them) and it’s been so fun reading an array from sci-fi to supernatural and now splatterpunk! I would say the gore factor is relatively digestible so if you’re looking to stick your hands into some yucky garland, give this a try! 🎁

Although you can’t buy this EXACT copy anymore as it was a limited run issue, you can read these stories in The Obituaries Collection Volume 1 which contains all the stories from the first 3 Obituaries issues!! 📚

(Also, @dj_volpe_horror story had a character that shared my name which I rarely see. It was ABSOLUTELY wild to read about a homicidal girl named Mona wielding weapons during a Holiday event. 🪓🤣 So thank you to him for that!)

A lovely collection of short horror stories from the wonderful Kealan Patrick Burke! 🖤 Perfect for this time of year although I will say unlike the previous holiday horror books I’ve been reading, this one is more about the winter season than the holidays specifically.

If I could describe this book in two words, I would say: SNOW and GRIEF. ❄️

My favorite of the collection is the first: Snowmen ⛄️ I kept thinking I knew where it was going and then BOOM! Dread. KPB has a unique writing style that really draws you in and I’m glad I finally got around to reading another of his books after reading Sour Candy. Turtle Boy is next on my list. 👀

I read Dead of Winter with @spencer.hamilton.books which I gotta start doing more often with short story collections especially. After every short story we messaged each other to talk about it and see each others thoughts and opinions. Buddy reading is so nice!!! So thank you to Spencer for reading this one with me!! ☺️❄️

Have you read this one? If you want something to read by the fire during a snowstorm that will definitely make the shadows in your room appear a lot darker, I recommend!!! ⛄️❄️⛄️❄️

I lean us both over and grab the bone-white palette knife from the easel ledge. I hold it before us, running my callused thumb over the blade. I take her hand and curl her palm around the handle. I carved this handle myself into intricate ribs that hit like acupressure points when pressed just right. She moans in pleasure as I constrict her grip for her. I’m around her like a petal-veined snake, hypnotizing her, sheathing her in decadence.

“I could paint you, if you’d like,” I whisper into her ear, sliding one tantalizing hand down the small of her belly. “I could paint you riding that phoenix all the way into the sunset.”

Her warm breath heightens as I bring the palette knife to her chest, tracing the rise and fall of her collarbones.

“I’d like that,” she says.

“Good.”

So with her assent, I run the edge of the knife across her throat, splitting the skin, the muscles, the cartilage. Color bursts forth in a grand arc, and it’s magnificent. Like parting space and time and creating heaven’s gates with one fell swoop. The arc weakens into a trickle as the heart continues to pump blood to a brain that will take another moment or two to die. It must have been shocking for her, given that palette knives are not meant to be so sharp, but as I’ve noted, I carved this one myself.

There is a gurgle, a pop from her throat as she drowns in her own blood, and I would reassure her in her dying moments that she will be immortalized forever, that viewers will come from far and wide just to catch a glimpse of her, but I am tired now and she is already dead.
Merry Christmas and Happy Holidays, ya ghoulies! 🥰🖤 What Christmas horror movie are you watching? I need recommendations! 🎄 🎅🏼 🎁

I watched Saltburn last night and it was absolutely phenomenal. It had everything I could possibly want in a psychological thriller. I don’t even want to go too deep into the plot, tropes, or conflict because I went in totally blind and feel it absolutely enhanced the experience. Just know it’s about an awkward college student trying to fit into prestigious Oxford life when he meets an alluring friend willing to share it all.

I really thought this movie was so great and I rarely rewatch movies but I’m going to have to make sure all my loved ones have seen this so it warrants as many rewatches as that takes.

But here’s a tangent I’ve been thinking about:

After diving into my social media apps, I have developed a new pet peeve. Whenever a horror or psychological thriller film is released, invariably a group will come out of the woodwork to say, “Oh, you thought that was crazy? Only people who haven’t seen xyz could possibly think that.” Or something to the effect of belittling and invalidating those who found enjoyment in a film. I literally just saw a Tiktok about how Saltburn is tame  in relation to these 5 films—and I have seen all those films and do not agree whatsoever! They’re different. They’re entirely different films and the belittling comparisons help no one.

This is not to say recommendations aren’t welcome. When I finish a movie I love, I immediately search for similar titles. But to make people feel silly for what they find joy in is simply not nice and does not increase the value of that persons “hot take” opinion.

I don’t know. That just really bothers me. Let people enjoy. Share and recommend in the hopes of exposing them to something new they’ll love. Be amazed we live in a world where so many different films and pieces of media can exist to affect people in different ways. Just, be kind and enjoy the damn show.

All this to say, watch Saltburn if you want. 😆 The end.

Happy New Year, my lovely ghouls! 🥂 I hope you all get to celebrate with loved ones and greet the new year with a smile.

I love the new year. I love goal setting and looking toward the future. I love resolutions and I love the feeling of the universe guiding me down new and lovelier paths. 🫀

I have many resolutions this year. One of the most important ones being to do what makes me happy in the moment rather than wait for the perfect time. I miss many happy opportunities because I stop myself from indulging when I don’t believe the timing is right. I’d like to be more free mentally. 🧠

I’d also like to publishing two books in 2024. Possibly three! But definitely two. 📚

I’d like to give more compliments and have more cheese and wine dates with my friends. I’d like to read more of what interests me rather than stick to a rigid tbr. I’d like to break away from a social media regimen and post what makes me happy when it makes me happy. And I’d like to achieve more and more success with my writing. Reach new audiences and meet new friends. 👁️

I hope your resolutions are decadent, I hope your night is sweet, and I hope your bed is warm. ☺️

Happy New Year! 🥳🖤

Are you a plotter or a pantser? ✍🏼

Personally, I’m a little of both but more pantser. Maybe 70% pantser and 30% plotter. When I begin a book, I always know how I want it to start and end. I know a few of the scenes in between I think will be impactful and some of the character development. But the rest is mostly just free fall. Although I plot along the way, I prefer it like this. I think the story tells me how it wants to be written and I’m just the fingers. 💅🏻

However, this does easily lead to potential plotholes and although they can be scary, I’ve never met a plothole I couldn’t fix. Sometimes it takes time, daydreaming, and intense introspection but there’s always a light at the end of the tunnel. 💡Sometimes the plothole fix isn’t where you think it is but somewhere far before. Sometimes it’s just a matter of a single detail.

All this to say write the way you want and when you encounter a plothole, mend it slowly and with care. Step by step, it will be filled. ☺️

“They say the sea is actually black and that it merely reflects the blue sky above. So it was with me. I allowed you to admire yourself in my eyes. I provided a service. I listened and listened and listened. You stored yourself in me.”

An anonymous alcoholic misogynist who enjoys emotionally traumatizing women gets a taste of his own medicine. And that’s about it. That’s the whole plot of this 151 page book. 😆

I picked this up because @xbadmoonrising spoke of it during his visit to NYC and then crazily enough, I found a copy of it in a Goodwill despite never having heard of the book before in my life. It was fate! I had to read it.

I think I went into this expecting some real traumatizing sh*t. Like some raunchy, awful details that would keep me awake all night,
staring at my ceiling wide eyed. Instead, it was more of a character study into the general thought processes of this anonymous man. The entire time I was trying to diagnose him; is he a narcissist? anti-social? is this a personality disorder or is he just a pig?

Which, as a psychology nerd, was really fun.

The Goodreads reviews for this book are generally negative and I can understand why. Nothing truly concrete or climactic happens in this little book and it reads a bit like a chauvinist’s manifesto but I was enthralled nonetheless. I found myself rooting for our anonymous pig in some sections once he meets his female counterpart but also hoping for the worst. What an interesting dissonance to experience!

I love reading into the minds of human monsters, seeing how they tick, appreciating their imperfections and insecurities. So, overall, I had fun. If you want a dark glimpse into a disturbed mind without too much second hand embarrassment or trauma, give this a read. 🤍

“Eat.”

A grieving mother unable to part with the body of her dead, 11 year old son cuts out a piece of his lung and places it in a jar. From that piece of lung, she expects only company—something to keep the memories of her child close. Instead, something grows. And it is hungry. 👄

I feel the word “bittersweet” is overused.  We believe many things to be bittersweet; the loss of a wailing child’s candy to a hungry bird, empty nesters experiencing their lonelier days now that their children are all grown up. And all of that is true but I’ve never experienced a fuller embodiment of “bittersweet” until Monstrilio; like crushing underripe berries between your teeth, your eyes watering with the violent ignition of your salivary glands. I was both so sad and so hopeful this entire story, volleying between the two states constantly like reapplying a sticky bandaid. 🦷

And the writing. My GOD the writing. Exquisite. Beautiful short sentences packed with imagery that cut like knives. I’m so glad I read this on my Kindle because I couldn’t unglue my eyes from the screen and the Kindle afforded me the ability to read the book while doing menial tasks. I was LOCKED IN for two days straight until I finished and now I feel a pit in my chest from never being able to experience this for the first time again. 👁️

The layers in this book are immense. There is so much to peel back and analyze. Grief as a catalyst for evolution, the moral dilemma of allowing one to give in to their true instincts, the domestication of ferocity. One could go on which is why this would be an EXCELLENT book club book. 📚

Monstrilio didn’t exactly make me cry as I thought it would, but it made me hope, and isn’t that better? 👹

Who doesn’t like a “good for her” moment? Revenge—sweet, sweet revenge—is so delectable. Especially in a horror book. 🖤

As an author, these scenes of unhinged rage are some of my favorite to write. I play some catastrophic music that makes me feel like my bones are made of dying stars and go to town. ✍🏼 I plan to include them in many books to come! 👄🦷 📚

What are your favorite scenes to write or read? 🖊️

“What is honor when you can barely survive?”

This city is rotting and the catalyst is the Unicorn Lounge. Located on top of a hill, the exclusive VIP club is run by the sleezy ex-pop star, Anthony Stine, where those of wealth can bring all their sordid fantasies to life. Detective Joeseph Stahl is doing all that his alcoholic, addiction-riddled mind will allow to keep this city safe but when the body of a young girl with a branded Unicorn matchbox washes up on the shore, he decides to turn to bloodshed—a vile, nightmarish justice. 🌃

What an excellent debut from Daniel Habib! I adore the gorey, crime noir elements of this novella—the seedy underground city the reader must navigate to collect whatever scraps of justice they can attain. I can still feel the dust, blood, and compact dirt on my skin from being transported to this grim landscape. Like a body horror infested Gotham. 🩸

The characters were all vibrant. Despite this being a shorter piece, I did not feel rushed in getting to know them and felt they were all well actualized—their needs, their fears, their desires. It’s difficult to find nobility in cityscapes like this and, in fact, my favorite character was one of the lowliest—Mr. Nightmare. Reading into his mind was like kissing the edge of a knife and being seduced by the cut. Absolutely riveting. 🔪

Although this novella could be read as a standalone, there is more to come. A little birdie tells me another book is in the works and I can’t wait to sink my teeth into the future of these characters. 🦷
